s.text: In the long run, even in this stock market, companies' stock prices will find their true level.

But what has become incredibly clear in 1999 is that the signal-to-noise ratio in the stock market is degenerating (with something like Piecyk's report being noise), and that means that it will take longer for those true levels to be reached.
And the truth is that there still isn't enough accountability for these kinds of forecasts to make the rewards and punishments for success and failure commensurate.
And the truth is that there still isn't enough accountability for these kinds of forecasts to make the rewards and punishments for success and failure commensurate.

When Henry Blodget, who was then at CIBC Oppenheimer, said that Amazon's shares would hit $400 within the year (he was right), it catapulted him into national attention and, in some sense, probably got him his new job at Merrill Lynch.
The phenomenon of number creep is bad because we want analysts to reach conclusions they think are true, and not conclusions that they think are going to get them on CNBC.
For a while now, the number everyone's been tossing around is $1.
In the long run, even in this stock market, companies' stock prices will find their true level.

When Henry Blodget, who was then at CIBC Oppenheimer, said that Amazon's shares would hit $400 within the year (he was right), it catapulted him into national attention and, in some sense, probably got him his new job at Merrill Lynch.
The best thing for everyone, then, will be for Qualcomm to settle back in the next couple of months, or even just rise slightly, and for Piecyk's forecast to be forgotten.
The best thing for everyone, then, will be for Qualcomm to settle back in the next couple of months, or even just rise slightly, and for Piecyk's forecast to be forgotten.
